sen.j: 甘樫坐神社（あまかしにますじんじゃ）は、奈良県高市郡明日香村の甘樫丘にある神社である。
sen.e: Amakashinimasu-jinja Shrine is located on Amakashi no oka Hill in Asuka-mura, Takaichi-gun, Nara Prefecture.
Amakashinimasu-jinja Shrine is located on Amakashi no oka Hill in Asuka-mura, Takaichi-gun, Nara Prefecture.
Amakashinimasu-jinja Shrine is located on Amakashi-no-oka Hill in Asuka-mura, Takaichi-gun, Nara Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 「Amakashi no oka Hill」を「Amakashi-no-oka Hill」に修正しました。

sen.j: 式内社で、旧社格は村社。
sen.e: It was a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws) and was categorized as a sonsha (a village shrine) in the old shrine ranking.
It was a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in ancient Engishiki laws) and was categorized as a sonsha (a village shrine) in the old shrine ranking.
It was a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in ancient Engishiki laws) and was categorized as a sonsha (a village shrine) in the old shrine ranking.
Enshrined Deity
Enshrined Deity
Enshrined Deity

sen.j: 推古天皇を主祭神とし、相殿に八幡宮・春日大明神・天照皇大神・八咫烏神・住吉大明神・熊野権現を祀る。
sen.e: The shrine enshrines Emperor Suiko as a shusaijin (main enshrined deities), and also enshrines Hachiman-gu no kami, Kasuga Daimyojin, Amaterasu Omikami, Yatagarasu no kami, Sumiyoshi Daimyojin and Kumano Gongen in the aidono (enshrinement of two or more deities in one building of a shrine).
sen.cmt: 原文に「八幡宮」とありますが、「八幡宮の神」として訳してあります。住吉大明神:http://www.nichibun.ac.jp/YoukaiCard/3630061.shtml
sen.e: The shrine enshrines Emperor Suiko as a shusaijin (main enshrined deity), and also enshrines Hachiman-gu no kami, Kasuga Daimyojin, Amaterasu Omikami, Yatagarasu no kami, Sumiyoshi Daimyojin and Kumano Gongen in the Aidono (annex).

The shrine enshrines Emperor Suiko as a shusaijin (main enshrined deity), and also enshrines Hachiman-gu no kami, Kasuga Daimyojin, Amaterasu Omikami, Yatagarasu no kami, Sumiyoshi Daimyojin and Kumano Gongen in the Aidono (annex).

sen.j: 『五郡神社記』には禍津日神・直毘神とあり、これが元々の祭神であった。
sen.e: Magatsuhi no kami (evil gods) and Naobi no kami (gods of restoration) mentioned in the "Gogun Jinja-ki" (Record of Shrines in Five Counties) are original deities.
Magatsuhi no kami (evil gods) and Naobi no kami (gods of restoration) are the original deities, as mentioned in the "Gogun Jinja-ki" (Record of Shrines in Five Counties).
Magatsuhi no kami (evil gods) and Naobi no kami (gods of restoration) are the original deities, as mentioned in the "Gogun Jinja-ki" (Record of Shrines in Five Counties).

sen.j: 推古天皇を主祭神とするようになったのは江戸時代以降のことである。
sen.e: After the Edo period, Emperor Suiko was enshrined as a shusaijin.
After the Edo period, Emperor Suiko was enshrined as a shusaijin.
After the Edo period, Emperor Suiko was enshrined as a shusaijin.
History
History
History

sen.j: 武内宿禰による創建と伝えられる。
sen.e: This shrine is said to have been founded by TAKENOUCHI no Sukune.
This shrine is said to have been founded by TAKENOUCHI no Sukune.
This shrine is said to have been founded by TAKENOUCHI no Sukune.

sen.j: 『日本三代実録』貞観 (日本)元年（859年）正月27日条に従五位下甘樫神に従五位上の神階を授けるという記述がある。
sen.e: There is a description in the Article from the 27th of January, 859 of the "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku" (sixth of the six classical Japanese history texts) stating that Amakashinimasu-jinja Shrine, the Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade was given the divine rank of the Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade.
sen.cmt: 原文の「甘樫神」は「甘樫坐神社」として訳してあります。
sen.e: In an Article dated January 27, 859 of the "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku" (the last of six classical Japanese history texts) it states that Amakashinimasu-jinja Shrine was promoted from Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade to Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade.
sen.cmt: there is a description > it states. was given the divine rank > was promoted
sen.e: In an Article dated January 27, 859 of the "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku" (the last of six classical Japanese history texts) it states that Amakashinimasu-jinja Shrine was promoted from Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade to Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳には「大和国高市郡 甘樫坐神社四座」と記載され、大社に列格、月次・相嘗・新嘗の奉幣に預ると記されている。
sen.e: It is listed as 'Amakashinimasu-jinja Shrine Shiza in Takaichi-gun, Yamato Province' in the Engishiki jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan) and is categorized as a taisya (a grand shrine) offering monthly Ainame-sai festival and Niiname-sai festival (ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to the deities).
sen.cmt: 甘樫坐神社四座: 定訳不明
sen.e: In the Engishiki jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan) it is listed as 'Amakashinimasu-jinja Shrine Shiza in Takaichi-gun, Yamato Province' and is categorised as a taisya (grand shrine) in charge of the monthly Ainame-sai and Niiname-sai festivals (ceremonial offering of newly-harvested rice by the Emperor to the deities).

In the Engishiki jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan) it is listed as 'Amakashinimasu-jinja Shrine Shiza in Takaichi-gun, Yamato Province' and is categorised as a taisha (grand shrine) in charge of the monthly Ainame-sai and Niiname-sai Festivals (ceremonial offering of newly-harvested rice by the Emperor to the deities).
sen.cmt: 「taisya」を「taisha」に修正しました。「festivals」を「Festivals」に修正しました。

sen.e: Shinto Ritual
Shinto Ritual
Shinto Ritual

sen.j: 甘樫丘は古代、盟神探湯が行われたという地である。
sen.e: Amakashi no oka Hill is the place where Kukatachi (a way of judging by putting one's hand in boiling water) was conducted in ancient times.
sen.cmt: 盟神探湯は読み方が「くかたち」、「くがたち」、「くかだち」とあるようです。訳文ではKukatachiを使用しています。一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Amakashi no oka Hill is the place where Kukatachi (a way of judging by putting one's hand in boiling water) was conducted in ancient times.
Amakashi-no-oka Hill is the place where Kukatachi (a way of judging by putting one's hand in boiling water) was conducted in ancient times.
sen.cmt: 「Amakashi no oka Hill」を「Amakashi-no-oka Hill」に修正しました。

sen.j: 中世の『五郡神社記』にも当社のことが「湯起請の神」と記されている。
sen.e: The shrine is described as 'yugisho no kami' (the god for testimonies with boiling water) in the "Gogun Jinja-ki" written in the medieval period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The shrine is described as 'yugisho no kami' (the god for testimonies with boiling water) in the "Gogun Jinja-ki" written in the medieval period.
The shrine is described as 'yugisho no kami' (the god for testimonies with boiling water) in the "Gogun Jinja-ki" written in the medieval period.

sen.j: これらのことに因んで、戦後、盟神探湯神事が行われるようになった。
sen.e: Remembering this tradition, Kukatachi-shinji (the ritual of Kukatachi) started being held after the war.
After the war, Kukatachi-shinji (the ritual of Kukatachi) started to be performed in honour of this tradition.
sen.cmt: remembering > in honour of. being held > to be performed.
sen.e: After the war, Kukatachi-shinji (the ritual of Kukatachi) started to be performed in honour of this tradition.
